{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3165157,"name":"joemost","username":"joemost","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joemost/{size}/11114_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-15T12:38:41.196Z","cooked":"

Our engaging works…but just takes too long.
Just the way our robots CG works, we can’t do the ‘lock when level’ or ‘lock when the pitch rate increases’.

By that point it is a lagging indicator for us, we basically roll back a set amount from that point. Which isn’t the worse approach but it forces us to have to go slower.

I’ve been toying with the idea of trying to use odometry/vision targets to do it. At that distance vision is fairly dead on. I haven’t looked under the hood about how odometry calculates but I’m a little afraid of inaccuracies there based on wheel slippage.

So I guess my question… for anyone that does this… how has it worked for you? I’m curious before we invest some time into this. I’ve realized in our robots case, we basically use the level as a normalizing point to try to find a very similar offset on the charging station every time.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-03-15T12:38:41.196Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":168,"readers_count":167,"score":78.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":430363,"topic_slug":"any-pure-odometry-vision-based-charging-station-levelers","display_username":"joemost","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/any-pure-odometry-vision-based-charging-station-levelers/430363/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3165162,"name":"Sanjith U","username":"sanjithar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sanjithar/{size}/193082_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-15T12:46:39.004Z","cooked":"

We tried this and it worked fairly well but it required us to be facing the camera around the target meaning we could only climb up in one orientation + unless you’re doing 3D pose estimation vía the tags and taking your gyro pitch into account the readings vary a bit with the angles of the charge station. We ended up just running a PID off the gyro pitch once all four wheels were fully on the ramp as that was easier to tune on practice fields without AprilTags and was generally faster and less shaky than the pure vision solution (though spending more time tuning probably could have improved that a bit).

There’s some discussion of this in the team 95 build thread:

FRC 95 The Grasshoppers 2023 Build Thread Open Alliance
Wait are teams doing this? we use the april tags but I had never thought to target a pose and balance purely off that. Kinda just assumed it would be too challenging to do so? I guess if you measure a pose that works for you, you could just drive to that though.

Good to know… yeah I’d love to just run a PID off the gyro pitch, but by the time we get an indication that it is tipping or leveling its too late, and we are too far down the ramp!
